speaker: Roz
text: Well I suppose you looked in the classifieds under "Housekeepers"?

speaker: Frasier
text: Check.

speaker: Roz
text: And you asked people in your building...

speaker: Frasier
text: Check.

speaker: Roz
text: And you called the employment agencies?

speaker: Frasier
text: Again, check.

speaker: Waiter
text: [_snidely_] I heard you the first time.

speaker: Roz
text: Who thought it'd be so hard to get to find someone to clean your house?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, over the years Daphne's managed to scour her way into our hearts, so to speak.  And I just don't want to hire someone who's only in it for the money.

speaker: Roz
text: So you want to find someone who's in it for the joy of cleaning? [_N.B. This is Gil's first appearance after being absent through the whole of Season Nine._]

speaker: Gil
text: Ah, may I?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, Gil.

speaker: Roz
text: Take a load off.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, nice outfit, Roz.  Somehow you and a peasant blouse just seem to go together.

speaker: Roz
text: [_rising_] Thanks.  Haven't worn it for years.  I mean, how long can something stay in the closet?

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, uh, Gil, are you pleased with your housekeeper?

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, you mean Chung?

speaker: Frasier
text: Mm-hmm.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh yes, he's marvelous.  He's efficient, he's dependable and he still hasn't figured out American money.  Between you and me, I told him when they made Lincoln's picture bigger it was worth more.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very funny.  Do you suppose that your Man Friday might be available on a Monday or a Tuesday?

speaker: Gil
text: You want to steal my Chung!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  Not steal him, just, just borrow him for a day or two a week until I can re-staff.

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, a dangerous notion, Frasier.  You know how employees gossip about their benefactors.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I have nothing to hide.

speaker: Gil
text: Yes, but suppose while on your premises he lets something slip about me and Deb and our heart-shaped bed?

speaker: Frasier
text: I would refuse to believe him.

speaker: Gil
text: Did I mention he's a drug mule?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, he is not!  You're just saying that because you don't want to help me out!

speaker: Gil
text: Oh, such insight.  It's a pity more people don't listen to your show. _He gets up and leaves as Frasier sits, fuming.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment Fade in. Frasier is escorting an applicant to the door.  Martin and Daphne are on chairs._

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you for coming, Mrs. Wilkins.  Of course, we have several other candidates to interview, but I'll be sure to let you know by the twelfth.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...of Never!  Honestly, I'm beginning to wonder if we'll ever find anyone that meets our standards.

speaker: Martin
text: You're being too picky.  It's just housekeeping, not rocket science.

speaker: Daphne
text: I beg to differ.  You don't even know half of what I used to do around here.  Like dusting the plant leaves or rotating your underwear.

speaker: Martin
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Daphne
text: Every month I used to throw out your oldest pair and put in two new pairs.  Did it ever occur to you that you didn't have to buy underwear in ten years?

speaker: Martin
text: Thought I got hold of a good batch.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now let's see, who is our front runner thus far?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I don't know, they're all the same to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Honestly, Dad, I am starting to get the slightest bit chaffed with your attitude.  You haven't even graded any of the candidates, you've simply doodled a war plane dropping bombs on a soldier.

speaker: Martin
text: That's not a soldier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then why is he wearing a helmet?

speaker: Martin
text: It's not a helmet.  It's someone with a big head! _Frasier gives him a dark look.  He then opens the door to reveal the next applicant._

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes?

speaker: Trish
text: Hi, I'm Trish Haney, I'm here about the housekeeper job? I'm really sorry I'm late.

speaker: Frasier
text: I had you down for over an hour ago.

speaker: Trish
text: I know.  I got stuck in line waiting to buy tickets to the Sonics game this weekend.

speaker: Martin
text: Really?  Come on in!

speaker: Trish
text: I should have guessed everyone and his brother would want to see Vince Carter play.

speaker: Martin
text: Not everybody.  Or his brother.

speaker: Trish
text: Wow, this is a beautiful place.  Here's my resume.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  Won't you be seated.  I'm Dr. Frasier Crane, this is my father Martin Crane and this is my sister-in-law Daphne Crane.  Now, I'll get right to the interview.  First question: What is the best way to combat rings on a wooden table?

speaker: Trish
text: Um, I heard you can rub mayonnaise on it.

speaker: Frasier
text: The best way is to provide coasters.  An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

speaker: Trish
text: [_smiling_] Started me out with a trick question.  Right.

speaker: Martin
text: So, how do you think the Sonics will defend Carter?

speaker: Trish
text: Um, you have to have someone body up on him and then double team when he gets the ball.

speaker: Martin
text: Thank you.

speaker: Daphne
text: Trish, if the washing machine has a twenty-five minute cycle, and the dryer has a forty minute cycle, what time does the second load have to go in the washer to be done by five o'clock?

speaker: Trish
text: Uh, well, that's sixty-five minutes, so 3:55.

speaker: Daphne
text: You may want to take some time to think about these questions before...

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, she's right.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_taken aback_] Well done.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I got a question: Can you clean a house?

speaker: Trish
text: Yes, and if I do say so myself, I'm pretty good.

speaker: Martin
text: Next question: Can you start Monday?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughing_] Well, we're getting just a bit ahead of ourselves. We still have several people to meet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you for coming by.

speaker: Trish
text: Oh, sure.  That was the interview, huh?  Two questions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it was really more of a pre-screening.  We'll be sure to let you know.

speaker: Trish
text: Oh, just to let you know, I'll be out of town until the first.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine, then I'll be sure to call you the second.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...I lose my mind!

speaker: Martin
text: What?  What was wrong with her?

speaker: Frasier
text: In the first place, she showed up late.  She doesn't take the interview seriously, how can we expect her to take the job seriously?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you just don't like her because she's not all stuffy.

speaker: Daphne
text: She did seem a bit cheeky.

speaker: Martin
text: Which YOU never were.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm afraid so far our best candidate is the young man from Jeepers Sweepers.

speaker: Martin
text: I will move out if you hire that prancing moron.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, fine.  Who would you hire?  This, this Trish, I suppose.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I was right about Daphne.  Doesn't that count for anything?  You didn't even want to hire her, you thought she might steal.

speaker: Daphne
text: Did you really say that?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course not!  I don't remember.

speaker: Martin
text: Well whoever gets hired is someone I'm gonna have to spend a lot of time with, and I don't need a lot of quiz questions and score sheets to get a feel for someone's character.

speaker: Daphne
text: Did I look like a thief?  Was it me shifty eyes?

speaker: Martin
text: Look, if you don't trust my judgment, Frasier, just have the guts to say so.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, all right, fine.  You can hire whoever you want to. You want this Trish, fine, call her.

speaker: Martin
text: Right.  I'll call her right now and tell her she's hired.

speaker: Daphne
text: And I'll tell her where you keep your valuables.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, would you give it a rest?! _FADE TO:  Scene Three -- Cafe Nervosa Fade in. Roz is at a table, ordering, and Niles is just coming in. _

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Niles, have a seat.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to waiter_] I'll have my usual.  Oh no, bottled water, room temperature.

speaker: Roz
text: Gee, slow down, little man, what are we celebrating?

speaker: Niles
text: I can't drink anything that's too hot, I have a toothache.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh.  You been to the dentist?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  He said the tooth is perfectly healthy but I still have this throbbing pain.  I think I may have to go to the doctor.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, it's probably just a sinus infection.  Have you had a cold lately?

speaker: Niles
text: Couple of weeks ago, yes, but I'm over it.

speaker: Roz
text: That's probably what it is, a sinus infection.  Happens to me all the time.

speaker: Niles
text: In all likelihood, I'm sure you're right.  Thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: Of course I'm right.  What else could it be?

speaker: Niles
text: Actually a toothache can be referred pain from something else.

speaker: Roz
text: "Referred pain."

speaker: Niles
text: That's right.  For example, if I had a heart condition, I might not have pain in my chest, I might have pain in my tooth.  You see, referred pain.  So while you're probably right about the sinus infection, let's not discount the one in ten thousand chance that it might be something more serious.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, now I get it.  So the pain in my butt might actually be coming from across the table.

speaker: Niles
text: Something like that, yes. [_He glances at the bottle top._] Oh look!  I'm the winner of a fanny pack.

speaker: Roz
text: Congratulations.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: You have no idea what it is, do you?

speaker: Niles
text: Not really, no.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, look: it says here the odds of winning it are one in ten thousand.  Ooh, spooky.  Same odds as that toothache being a heart attack.  Maybe it's a sign.

speaker: Niles
text: It's a good sign.  By beating those odds once it makes it that much more unlikely that something so improbable can happen to me again.

speaker: Woman
text: Niles! _Niles gets up, but it is not his wife.  The woman crosses over to another table where a young man rises to greet her._

speaker: Other Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, that's weird. **IN STREET JARGON, HE'S KNOW AS "THE MARK"** _Scene Four - Frasier's Apartment Fade in. Martin is showing Trish around._

speaker: Martin
text: So, that's the grand tour.

speaker: Trish
text: Hard to know where to start.  I don't have much time before I have to go.

speaker: Martin
text: What?  You leavin' already?

speaker: Trish
text: Yeah, I have this lunch thing.  I hope you don't mind.

speaker: Martin
text: Well...

speaker: Trish
text: The problem is, it's this friend that I've been putting off because I've been too busy, but now I finally don't have any excuse.  We're gonna try that new rib place down in Bell Town.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I hear that's great.

speaker: Trish
text: Yeah, I can bring you back a great big bag of them.  But enough chit chat, I've got dishes to do.

speaker: Martin
text: Hold on, can I offer a suggestion?

speaker: Trish
text: You're the boss.

speaker: Martin
text: What Daphne did was put a load of laundry in first and that way you can do two things at once.

speaker: Trish
text: Okay.  Although I prefer to do laundry at the end of the day, and that way I can read when the clothes are in the dryer. I mean it's about the only "me time" I have on this job.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad, ready for breakfast?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, thanks for the invite, but I can't go.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we didn't invite you.  You called us and badgered us until we rearranged our schedule.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that was before Trish came.  I really think I should hang around and show her the ropes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Maybe you should show her where the room freshener is. It smells like stale cigars in here.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I had some of the guys in last night for poker.  Oh, hey!  Niles, check this out.  I've got a great new card trick.

speaker: Niles
text: [_resigned_] Oh, goody.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, it's called "The Amazing Niles."  Or "The Amazing..." whoever you're doing the trick with.  Like, if I was doing it with Daphne, it'd be "The Amazing Daphne."  Or if I was doing it with Frasier, it'd be...

speaker: Niles
text: "The Amazing Frasier", yeah, I get it, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  That's just my patter.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, Amazing Niles, I want you to draw the ace of spades out of this deck.

speaker: Niles
text: [_humoring him_] Ah, something tells me that it's going to be this one right here. _He pulls a card then turns it over to show that it is the ace of spades._

speaker: Martin
text: Ladies and gentlemen, he drew the ace of spades!

speaker: Daphne
text: Amazing, Amazing Niles.

speaker: Martin
text: Isn't that a great trick?

speaker: Daphne
text: Hey, wait a minute.  How come this deck only has aces of spades?

speaker: Martin
text: What?  No, THIS is the trick...

speaker: Martin
text: Wait a minute, this isn't the trick deck.  Holy cow!

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: You just drew the card I asked you for.  What are the odds? I wonder if you can do it again.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  Only one performance a day.

speaker: Daphne
text: Is something wrong?

speaker: Niles
text: What?  No.  You know, since we're not going to have breakfast, maybe we should go.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.  That way we can pick up your car from the shop.

speaker: Martin
text: What happened to your car?

speaker: Niles
text: [_quietly_] Got struck by lightning.

speaker: Trish
text: Okay, washer's running as we speak.  Anything else before I go?

speaker: Martin
text: You're going to lunch now?  It's only ten.

speaker: Trish
text: Already?  Ugh, I guess the dishes'll have to wait.  I've got a couple of errands to run and then I have a hair appointment.

speaker: Martin
text: Trish, I'm a little surprised that you're takin' off like this.

speaker: Trish
text: Yeah.  I'm a little surprised too.  I thought my first day would be more like orientation, you know?  Show me around, explain my duties, and then I start work the next day.

speaker: Martin
text: Why would you think that?

speaker: Trish
text: It's been that way every other place I've worked.  And I've had a lot of jobs.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, listen Trish, I kinda went out on a limb for you and I'll never hear the end of it from my son if you let me down.

speaker: Trish
text: Don't worry, you are not gonna regret hiring me.  Tomorrow morning, I'll be like the White Tornado.  Remember those commercials, the White Tornado?  That'll be me, ten o'clock.

speaker: Martin
text: So, you're not comin' back after lunch?

speaker: Trish
text: Oh, trust me, you don't want me cleaning this place drunk. And that reminds me, I don't work Mondays.  Gosh, you know, I better get going.  If I'm late to this lunch, how's that gonna look?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what about the laundry?

speaker: Trish
text: Oh, ten o'clock tomorrow.  Along with those ribs.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I hear the washer going.  I assume that means our new employee is hard at it.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah, she's like the White Tornado.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you know your basketball references go right over my head.  You know, she's certainly got her work cut out for her, cleaning up this mess you and your buddies made last night.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you don't have to worry about it, she's all about the work.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Dad, I think I owe you an apology.

speaker: Martin
text: For what?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for thinking I was a better judge of people than you are.  I just want you to know that I do trust your judgment. Maybe I don't say that often enough.  Anyway, I hope you can forgive me.

speaker: Martin
text: There's nothing to forgive, Son.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.  I'll see you later. _He leaves.  Eddie comes in and jumps on the arm of Martin's chair, a toy in his mouth._

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting up_] Not now, boy.  We've got an apartment to clean. _FADE OUT  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene One - Caf e Nervosa_ Fade in. Roz is sitting at the window table, reading a magazine.  Niles comes in, looking desperate. _

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Niles.  How's it goin'?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm as good as dead! [_sitting_] I've been doing research into my family health history: my great-uncle Timothy keeled over from a heart attack at my age.

speaker: Niles
text: [_urgently_] Bottled water.  Please.

speaker: Roz
text: Are you talking about that tooth again?

speaker: Niles
text: It's still throbbing, thank you!  Which means my heart is probably on its last legs.

speaker: Roz
text: Come on, Niles, you said it was a one in a million chance.

speaker: Niles
text: One in ten thousand.  And I've been beating those odds all week.  I don't believe in omens, but these are getting harder and harder to ignore.

speaker: Roz
text: So are you.

speaker: Niles
text: I flipped a coin seventeen times last night and every time it came up tails!  I only stopped because I was getting a blister.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: How does Daphne put up with all this?

speaker: Niles
text: I haven't told her about it.  Because, unlike you, she'd worry about me.

speaker: Roz
text: Get your heart checked.  And stop obsessing about it.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm going to.  In all probability, there's a perfectly reasonable expla... _Glancing at the bottle cap, he drops it and pulls back with a gasp of shock._

speaker: Roz
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: I won another fanny pack! _He sits frozen as Roz checks the cap.  FADE TO:  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment Fade in. Martin is mopping the floor just inside the front door, the phone pressed to his ear._

speaker: Martin
text: No, I'm not mad at you, Trish, I'm just a little disappointed. Well, yesterday was your neighbor's funeral and today you got the flu.  No, I kinda believe you, but you know this apartment doesn't clean itself, so... huh?  Okay.  Tomorrow, nine sharp.  Ten?  Okay.  I'll see you when you get here. _He hears the key in the lock and quickly puts the mop in the powder room.  Frasier comes in, dropping his wet galoshes and struggling with his dripping umbrella._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, for God's sake!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, careful there mister.  You're gonna get water all over the clean floor.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, maybe you can have Trish wax this floor tomorrow.

speaker: Martin
text: She already did.  It took her two hours.  And it just took you two seconds to mess it up and start complaining.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well I'm not complaining, Dad, but look at these streaks here.  It's like she never waxed a floor before.

speaker: Martin
text: All you do is nag, nag, nag!  Meanwhile she tried a new fabric softener on your sweater and you didn't even notice!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, my sweaters are supposed to be dry-cleaned.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, and remind me to say something to her about flipping my mattress.

speaker: Martin
text: What the hell are you trying to do, kill her?

speaker: Frasier
text: Easy, easy.  Dad, there's no reason to get all riled up. My God, you're actually perspiring.

speaker: Martin
text: Well I just think some people around here don't realize how hard she works.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'll say this much: the place does smell lemony fresh.

speaker: Martin
text: That shows what you know.  It's country breeze. _He grabs at some papers on the coffee table.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Niles' Apartment Fade in. Daphne is straightening up in the living room.  Niles comes down the stairs._

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, I have to go out for a while.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.

speaker: Niles
text: No place out of the ordinary, just... out.

speaker: Daphne
text: Okay.  See you later. _She walks away to the other side of the room without looking at him. He gets his jacket.  As he puts it on he begins thinking._

speaker: Niles
text: [_voice over of thoughts_] I can't believe this is happening. After all those misspent years of frustration and yearning, I finally find the fulfillment of my dreams only to have it snatched away.  Look at her.  She's so beautiful, so perfect. She deserves nothing but happiness.  I hope, when I'm gone, she's able to make a life with someone else.  After a suitable period of mourning, of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: [_emotionally_] Yes, my love?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_firmly_] WHEN are you going to change the paper in the bottom of the bird cage, hmm?  I've asked you three times already.

speaker: Niles
text: Soon as I get back.

speaker: Niles
text: [_v.o._] Maybe when I'm gone, Her Majesty can muck out her own birdcage. _He leaves.  FADE TO:  Scene Four - Frasier's Apartment Fade in. Martin is in the kitchen, polishing the silverware and talking on the phone._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras, sorry to bother ya.  Trish was wondering where you keep the silver polish.  Right, I told her about that tarnish on your shrimp fork.

speaker: Martin
text: She suggested a place you could keep it where the air won't get to it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really.  Perhaps she and I could have a discussion about that.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you doin' here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, my lunch cancelled, I thought I might drop by, see if you might like to join me for a bite.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, sure, love to.  Let me get my coat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, I'll just tell Trish that we're leaving.  Where is she?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, uh, she's in the powder room.  Let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, Dad, I'd rather wait.  You see, I wanted to discuss a new vacuuming pattern with her.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, actually, Fras, this might not be a good time. That shrimp fork thing really set her off. She kinda went to pieces and locked herself in there.

speaker: Frasier
text: She did?  I had no idea she was so fragile.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, she'll get over it.  She just needs to be alone for a while, she'll be fine. [_calling_] Bye, Trish!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Dad.  You know, if I've hurt her feelings, then it is incumbent upon me to apologize.

speaker: Martin
text: Well...

speaker: Frasier
text: Trish, it's Dr. Crane.  Could you come out here, please? I'd like to have a word with you.

speaker: Martin
text: The old silent treatment.  Well, two can play that game. Let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Dad, why don't you talk to her?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I don't think so.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, Dad, she likes you.  Please.

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, Trish?  Hi, it's Marty.  Listen, I know you're upset, but I'd like to talk to you.  Um, would you unlock the door? _He opens the door a very small amount and slips in, blocking Frasier's view._

speaker: Martin
text: Thatta girl. _He closes the door behind him.  Frasier looks put off.  Martin comes back out a moment later._

speaker: Martin
text: All right, you just take all the time you need.

speaker: Martin
text: She accepted your apology but she just wants to be alone for a little while, so let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I really should apologize to her in person.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't think this is the time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why not?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you have been pretty critical.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I also think that she's made some real improvements around here.  Tell her that. _Martin, a little exasperated, goes back into the powder room.  After a moment, he sticks his face back out the door._

speaker: Martin
text: She wants an example.

speaker: Frasier
text: How should I know?  Make something up.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, no wonder she's mad, you ungrateful sonofabitch! _He closes the door on Frasier's stunned look.  A moment later, Trish comes in the front door.  Frasier, looking perturbed, motions her to be silent.  Martin comes out as Frasier rocks on his heels smugly._

speaker: Martin
text: All right, see you later.  Well, now I think you made things worse.  It wouldn't surprise me if she didn't come in tomorrow. _Noticing where Frasier is looking, he glances back.  Looking guilty and without anything to say, he slowly sticks his head back into the powder room._

speaker: Martin
text: You didn't tell me you had a sister.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!  All right, what the hell is going on?

speaker: Trish
text: No idea.  I just came by for my paycheck.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, uh, I got some bad news about that, Trish.  I'm sorry, but we're gonna have to let you go.

speaker: Trish
text: Oh.  Okay, but you still owe me for the days I was supposed to be here last week.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure, sure.  And there'll be a check in the mail sometime after the first.

speaker: Martin
text: ...asteroid hits Earth!  [_N.B. Ana Gasteyer previously filmed an appearance as a physical therapist for[[_10.11_]](1011), "Door Jam," but that episode wound up being shelved.  It was reworked and aired three months after its originally scheduled October air date, without her subplot._]  _FADE TO:  Scene Five - A Doctor's Office Fade in. Niles is waiting in a chair.  The doctor comes in and stands behind his desk, holding a chart._

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, lay it on me.  I'm prepared for the worst.  Is it my heart?

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm afraid so.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah-ha!

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Doctor
text: There is an anomaly in your EKG.  I'm gonna have to check you into the hospital.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, uh, well, hmm.  Uh, I guess I can clear my schedule. How's, how's tomorrow afternoon?

speaker: Doctor
text: No, no.  Niles?  You need to go right now. _Niles simply sits there, stunned.  FADE OUT  END OF ACT TWO_
